title: ICASSP_2016_11_abs

sentences.text: The problem of blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals is addressed through a method relying on nonstationarity of the original signals .
The signals are assumed to be piecewise stationary with varying variances in different epochs .
In comparison with previous works , in this paper it is assumed that the signals are not i.i.d. in each epoch , but obey a first-order autoregressive model .
This model was shown to be more appropriate for blind separation of natural speech signals .
A separation method is proposed that is nearly statistically efficient -LRB- approaching the corresponding Cramér-Rao lower bound -RRB- , if the separated signals obey the assumed model .
In the case of natural speech signals , the method is shown to have separation accuracy better than the state-of-the-art methods .

Entity-this_paper.label: this paper
Entity-this_paper.description: This paper presents a method for blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals, assuming that the signals follow a first-order autoregressive model rather than being independent and identically distributed, which is shown to be more effective for natural speech signals.

Entity-a_separation_method.label: A separation method
Entity-a_separation_method.description: A separation method that utilizes the nonstationarity of piecewise stationary signals and a first-order autoregressive model to achieve nearly statistically efficient blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals, particularly natural speech signals.

Entity-separation_method.label: separation method
Entity-separation_method.description: The separation method refers to a proposed algorithm for blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals, which utilizes a first-order autoregressive model to achieve nearly statistically efficient separation accuracy, particularly for natural speech signals.

Entity-method.label: method
Entity-method.description: The method refers to a proposed technique for blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals, which utilizes the nonstationarity of the signals and assumes a first-order autoregressive model to achieve separation accuracy superior to existing state-of-the-art methods.

Entity-blind_separation_of_natural_speec.label: blind separation of natural speech signals
aliases: blind separation of natural speech signals
Entity-blind_separation_of_natural_speec.description: Blind separation of natural speech signals refers to a signal processing method that aims to extract individual speech signals from a mixture of overlapping audio sources without prior knowledge of the sources, utilizing statistical models to account for the nonstationarity and autoregressive characteristics of the speech signals.

mentions.local_name: blind separation of natural speech signals

Entity-blind_separation_of_underdetermin.label: blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals
aliases: blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals
Entity-blind_separation_of_underdetermin.description: The term 'blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals' refers to a computational problem and methodology aimed at extracting individual source signals from a mixture where the number of sources exceeds the number of observed mixtures, utilizing statistical properties and nonstationarity of the signals.

mentions.local_name: blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals

Entity-blind_separation.label: blind separation
Entity-blind_separation.description: Blind separation is a signal processing technique used to extract individual source signals from a mixture without prior knowledge of the sources or the mixing process.

Entity-original_signal.label: original signals
Entity-original_signal.description: The term 'original signals' refers to the independent signals that are being analyzed for blind separation in the context of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures, characterized by their nonstationarity and piecewise stationary properties.

Entity-this_model.label: This model
Entity-this_model.description: This model refers to a first-order autoregressive model that is assumed to describe the behavior of signals in the context of blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures, particularly for natural speech signals.

Entity-nonstationarity_of_the_original_s.label: nonstationarity of the original signals
Entity-nonstationarity_of_the_original_s.description: The nonstationarity of the original signals refers to the characteristic of the signals being analyzed, which exhibit variations in their statistical properties, such as mean and variance, over time, and are modeled as piecewise stationary with different variances in distinct epochs, thereby influencing the effectiveness of blind separation techniques for underdetermined mixtures.

Entity-model.label: model
Entity-model.description: The 'model' refers to a first-order autoregressive model that is assumed to describe the behavior of piecewise stationary signals for the purpose of blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals, particularly in the context of natural speech signals.

Entity-separated_signal.label: separated signals
Entity-separated_signal.description: Separated signals refer to the independent signals that have been extracted from a mixture using a proposed separation method that relies on the nonstationarity and first-order autoregressive properties of the original signals.

Entity-signal.label: signals
Entity-signal.description: The term 'signals' refers to the independent signals that are being analyzed and separated in the context of blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures, specifically focusing on natural speech signals that exhibit piecewise stationarity and varying variances.

Entity-the_signal.label: The signals
Entity-the_signal.description: The signals refer to independent signals that are piecewise stationary with varying variances across different time epochs, specifically in the context of blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures.

Entity-independent_signal.label: independent signals
Entity-independent_signal.description: Independent signals refer to distinct sources of data that can be separated from a mixture in the context of blind source separation, particularly in scenarios involving nonstationary and piecewise stationary characteristics.

Entity-assumed_model.label: assumed model
Entity-assumed_model.description: The 'assumed model' refers to a first-order autoregressive model that the signals are expected to follow in order to achieve nearly statistically efficient separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals.

Entity-separation_accuracy.label: separation accuracy
Entity-separation_accuracy.description: Separation accuracy refers to the effectiveness of a proposed method in correctly isolating independent signals from a mixture, specifically demonstrating superior performance in separating natural speech signals compared to existing state-of-the-art techniques.

Entity-underdetermined_instantaneous_mix.label: underdetermined instantaneous mixtures
Entity-underdetermined_instantaneous_mix.description: Underdetermined instantaneous mixtures refer to a problem in signal processing where multiple independent signals are mixed together in such a way that there are fewer observed signals than the number of original sources, making it challenging to separate them without additional information or assumptions about their properties.

Entity-statistically_efficient.label: statistically efficient
Entity-statistically_efficient.description: The term 'statistically efficient' refers to a property of an estimation method that achieves performance close to the Cramér-Rao lower bound, indicating that the method provides estimates with the lowest possible variance among all unbiased estimators, particularly in the context of separating signals that follow a first-order autoregressive model.

Entity-different_epoch.label: different epochs
Entity-different_epoch.description: Different epochs refer to distinct time intervals during which the statistical properties of the signals, such as variance, change, allowing for the analysis of nonstationary signals in the context of blind separation methods.

Entity-cramr-rao_lower_bound.label: Cramér-Rao lower bound
Entity-cramr-rao_lower_bound.description: The Cramér-Rao lower bound is a theoretical limit that provides a lower bound on the variance of estimators of a parameter, indicating the best possible precision that can be achieved in estimating that parameter under certain conditions.

Entity-each_epoch.label: each epoch
Entity-each_epoch.description: In the context of the paper, 'each epoch' refers to distinct time intervals during which the statistical properties of the signals, such as variance, may change, and within which the signals are modeled as following a first-order autoregressive process rather than being independent and identically distributed.

Entity-piecewise_stationary.label: piecewise stationary
Entity-piecewise_stationary.description: Piecewise stationary refers to a property of a signal or process where it exhibits different statistical characteristics, such as mean and variance, in distinct segments or intervals of time.

Entity-nonstationarity.label: nonstationarity
Entity-nonstationarity.description: Nonstationarity refers to a property of a signal or statistical process where its statistical characteristics, such as mean and variance, change over time, indicating that the process does not have a constant distribution.

Entity-first-order_autoregressive_model.label: first-order autoregressive model
Entity-first-order_autoregressive_model.description: A first-order autoregressive model is a statistical model used in time series analysis where the current value of a variable is regressed on its immediately preceding value, capturing temporal dependencies.

Entity-varying_variance_in_different_epo.label: varying variances in different epochs
Entity-varying_variance_in_different_epo.description: The phrase 'varying variances in different epochs' refers to the characteristic of signals being analyzed in the study, indicating that the statistical variance of these signals changes over distinct time periods or segments, which is a key aspect of their piecewise stationary nature.

Entity-natural_speech_signal.label: natural speech signals
Entity-natural_speech_signal.description: Natural speech signals refer to the audio signals produced by human speech, encompassing the various sounds, tones, and patterns used in verbal communication.

Entity-varying_variance.label: varying variances
Entity-varying_variance.description: Varying variances refer to the changing statistical dispersion of signals over different time epochs in a piecewise stationary context, indicating that the variability of the signals is not constant but fluctuates across segments of time.

Entity-variance.label: variances
Entity-variance.description: In the context of the paper, 'variances' refers to the statistical measure of the dispersion of signal amplitudes that change over different time epochs in piecewise stationary signals.

Entity-i.i.d_..label: i.i.d.
Entity-i.i.d_..description: i.i.d. stands for 'independent and identically distributed', a statistical property describing a set of random variables that are all drawn from the same probability distribution and are mutually independent.

Entity-state-of-the-art_method.label: state-of-the-art methods
Entity-state-of-the-art_method.description: state-of-the-art methods refer to the most advanced and effective techniques or approaches currently available in a particular field, serving as a benchmark for comparison.

Entity-epoch.label: epochs
Entity-epoch.description: Epochs refer to distinct periods or intervals of time characterized by specific conditions or events.

Entity-previous_work.label: previous works
Entity-previous_work.description: previous works refers to earlier research studies or academic literature that have been published on a particular topic.

summary: The problem of blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals is addressed through a method relying on nonstationarity of the original signals . The signals are assumed to be piecewise stationary with varying variances in different epochs . In comparison with previous works , in this paper it is assumed that the signals are not i.i.d. in each epoch , but obey a first-order autoregressive model . This model was shown to be more appropriate for blind separation of natural speech signals . A separation method is proposed that is nearly statistically efficient -LRB- approaching the corresponding Cramér-Rao lower bound -RRB- , if the separated signals obey the assumed model . In the case of natural speech signals , the method is shown to have separation accuracy better than the state-of-the-art methods .

Predicate-is_addressed_through.label: is addressed through
Predicate-is_addressed_through.description: The predicate 'is addressed through' indicates a relationship where the subject is approached, resolved, or managed by means of the object. It suggests that the object provides a method, framework, or context that facilitates the understanding or solution of the issue or concept represented by the subject.

Predicate-addresses.label: addresses
Predicate-addresses.description: The predicate 'addresses' indicates that the subject is concerned with, deals with, or provides a solution to the issue or concept represented by the object. It establishes a relationship where the subject is actively engaging with the object, often implying a focus on resolving, analyzing, or responding to the complexities or challenges associated with the object.

Predicate-are_assumed_to_be.label: are assumed to be
Predicate-are_assumed_to_be.description: The predicate 'are assumed to be' indicates a belief or hypothesis regarding the nature or characteristics of the subject, suggesting that the subject is considered to possess the qualities or state described by the object. It implies a level of uncertainty or conjecture, where the object represents a presumed condition or classification that the subject is thought to fulfill.

Predicate-are_in.label: are in
Predicate-are_in.description: The predicate 'are in' indicates a relationship of inclusion or presence, where the subject exists within the context or framework defined by the object. It suggests that the subject is situated or located in the realm represented by the object, implying a connection that can be temporal, spatial, or categorical.

Predicate-have.label: have
Predicate-have.description: The predicate 'have' indicates a relationship of possession or association between the subject and the object, where the subject possesses, contains, or is characterized by the qualities or attributes described by the object. In this context, it signifies that the subject exhibits or includes the features or properties represented by the object.

Predicate-are_not.label: are not
Predicate-are_not.description: The predicate 'are not' serves to establish a negation or denial relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject does not possess the characteristics or qualities defined by the object. It asserts that the subject is distinct from or incompatible with the object in some way.

Predicate-obey.label: obey
Predicate-obey.description: The predicate 'obey' indicates a relationship in which the subject acts in accordance with, or follows the directives or rules set by, the object. This implies a hierarchical or authoritative connection where the subject recognizes the object as a source of guidance or control, leading to compliance or adherence to the object's stipulations.

Predicate-assumes.label: assumes
Predicate-assumes.description: The predicate 'assumes' indicates that the subject takes a particular stance, belief, or position regarding the object. It suggests that the subject accepts the object as true or valid without requiring proof or evidence, often as a foundational element for further reasoning or argumentation.

Predicate-is_in.label: is in
Predicate-is_in.description: The predicate 'is in' establishes a relationship of inclusion or presence between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject exists within the context, scope, or content of the object. It suggests that the subject is part of, contained by, or associated with the object in a meaningful way.

Predicate-is_obeyed_by.label: is obeyed by
Predicate-is_obeyed_by.description: The predicate 'is obeyed by' indicates a relationship where the subject is a set of rules, principles, or models that are followed or adhered to by the object. It implies that the object acts in accordance with the guidelines or expectations set forth by the subject, suggesting a directional influence where the subject dictates behavior or outcomes that the object conforms to.

Predicate-shown_to_be_more_appropriate_f.label: shown to be more appropriate for
Predicate-shown_to_be_more_appropriate_f.description: The predicate 'shown to be more appropriate for' indicates that the subject has been demonstrated or evidenced to be better suited or more fitting for the context or application represented by the object. It implies a comparative evaluation where the subject is recognized as having advantages or superior qualities in relation to the specific scenario or task described by the object.

Predicate-is_proposed.label: is proposed
Predicate-is_proposed.description: The predicate 'is proposed' indicates that the subject is being suggested or put forward as a potential solution, idea, or approach related to the object. It implies a recommendation or an introduction of a concept that is intended for consideration, evaluation, or further development.

Predicate-is_statistically_efficient.label: is statistically efficient
Predicate-is_statistically_efficient.description: The predicate 'is statistically efficient' establishes a relationship between a subject and an object by indicating that the subject achieves optimal performance in terms of statistical estimation or inference, as defined by the object. In this context, the object often represents a benchmark or standard, such as the Cramér-Rao lower bound, which quantifies the best possible accuracy or precision that can be attained by an estimator. Thus, when a subject is described as 'statistically efficient,' it implies that it operates at or near this optimal level, minimizing variance or maximizing information gain relative to the specified standard.

Predicate-is_shown_to_have.label: is shown to have
Predicate-is_shown_to_have.description: The predicate 'is shown to have' indicates that the subject possesses or demonstrates a certain quality, characteristic, or attribute represented by the object. It implies that there is evidence or proof supporting the claim that the subject exhibits the specified property, thereby establishing a relationship of validation or confirmation between the subject and the object.

Predicate-is_better_than.label: is better than
Predicate-is_better_than.description: The predicate 'is better than' establishes a comparative relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject possesses a higher quality, performance, or effectiveness in a specific context compared to the object. This comparison suggests a superiority of the subject over the object in the relevant domain.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates that the subject is introducing, showcasing, or delivering information, findings, or concepts related to the object. It implies a formal or structured communication of the object, which can be a method, idea, or result, often in a context such as a report, presentation, or academic paper.

Predicate-is_a_specific_instance_of.label: is a specific instance of
Predicate-is_a_specific_instance_of.description: The predicate 'is a specific instance of' establishes a relationship between a subject and an object where the subject represents a particular example or case that falls under the broader category defined by the object. This indicates that the subject shares characteristics or properties with the object, thus categorizing the subject as a member of the class or type denoted by the object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a specific instance or type that falls under the more general category represented by the object. This relationship suggests that the subject is a subset or a particular example of the broader concept denoted by the object.
